stem: A 68-year-old client with a urinary tract infection (UTI) is found to be confused and hypotensive. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: I am calling about Mr. Jones in room 302. He is showing signs of septic shock, likely secondary to his UTI.
Background: Mr. Jones is a 68-year-old male admitted for urosepsis. He has a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and diabetes mellitus.
Assessment: At 07:00, the client was found to be disoriented to person and place. His skin is mottled and cool to the touch. Vital Signs: BP 82/50 mmHg, HR 128 bpm, RR 28 breaths/min, T 102.8°F (39.3°C), SpO2 93% on 2L NC. Serum lactate is 5.2 mmol/L, and MAP is 58 mmHg. WBC count is 24,000/mm³. Blood cultures are pending.
Recommendation: I recommend implementing the sepsis bundle immediately, including fluid resuscitation and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

actionOptions.text: Administer 30 mL/kg IV bolus of 0.9% Normal Saline
Apply a cooling blanket to rapidly drop temp to 100.4°F (38°C)
Administer Beta-blockers to decrease the heart rate

rationale.correct: Septic Shock (c2) is defined by persistent hypotension (MAP < 65 mmHg) despite fluid resuscitation and a lactate > 2 mmol/L. The client's presentation (confusion, mottled skin, elevated temperature, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, elevated lactate and WBC) supports this diagnosis. Priority interventions include rapid fluid boluses (a1) to restore volume and broad-spectrum antibiotics (a2) to treat the source of infection. The primary parameters to monitor are MAP (p1) to evaluate perfusion and lactate (p2) to evaluate cellular hypoxia/anaerobic metabolism. Trends in these values will help determine the effectiveness of interventions.
clinicalPearls: In the 'Sepsis Six' or 1-hour bundle, culture collection MUST happen before antibiotics if possible, but antibiotics should not be delayed more than 45–60 mins.
Lactate is the best indicator of 'hidden' shock and tissue hypoperfusion.
If MAP doesn't respond to fluids, Norepinephrine (Levophed) is the first-line vasopressor.

questionTrap.trap: Waiting for cultures to return before giving antibiotics.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Collect the cultures, then give the antibiotics immediately. Waiting 24–48 hours for a growth report is fatal in septic shock.
